bug.author: Mahdi-Hosseinali
bug.summary: object string shows when using the new beta_columns for styling
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h1>Summary</denchmark-h>
beta_columns shows the object string of st.dataframe when pandas styling is used <denchmark-h:h1>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
import numpy as np import streamlit as st
tmp_df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(3, 4)) left_c, right_c = st.beta_columns(2) left_c.write(st.dataframe(tmp_df.style.highlight_min(axis=0))) <denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior:</denchmark-h>
Just show the dataframe <denchmark-h:h2>Actual behavior:</denchmark-h>
shows the object string like the following: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/31252766/97473255-2c226980-1921-11eb-9a55-b2b6bbec51ae.png></denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h2>Is this a regression?</denchmark-h>
no <denchmark-h:h1>Debug info</denchmark-h>
Streamlit version: 0.69.2 Python version: 3.83 Conda OS version: Windows 10 Home (1909) Browser version: Chrome Version 86.0.4240.75

comments.comment: I should mention that when I use magic with containers the object string doesn't show.

Hi <denchmark-link:https://github.com/Mahdi-Hosseinali>@Mahdi-Hosseinali</denchmark-link> , thanks for the detailed repro steps! This is actually caused by the way you've called dataframes. <denchmark-code>left_c.write(st.dataframe(tmp_df.style.highlight_min(axis=0))) </denchmark-code>
is equivalent to outside of the column: <denchmark-code>st.write(st.dataframe(tmp_df.style.highlight_min(axis=0))) </denchmark-code>
Which will also show the object string. Instead, the code you're looking for is: <denchmark-code>left_c.dataframe(tmp_df.style.highlight_min(axis=0)) </denchmark-code>
Much simpler!
